Chapter 6: Kindness (2)
Merchants traveling through the wilderness, hungry and thirsty on a perilous road,
The guide rescues and protects them, leading them to a place with fruit and water.
Using the unconditioned path, they eliminate all defilements and poisons,
Accumulating peace and attaining equanimity, I bow my head to the World-Honored Buddha.
The ship was in the great ocean, heading towards the mouth of the fish Makara,
The ship entered the fish's belly, and with compassion they were saved.
In the moment before sinking, they saved people and precious treasures,
Knowing the countless hundreds of thousands of the suffering and joy of birth and death;
Surpassing the sages of the past, their virtue like a great mountain,
The wisdom of the path surpassing the sunlight, I vow to bow my head to the wise one.
Those who practice the path should abandon anger and always follow a compassionate mind;
Some practitioners only make vows with their mouths to bring peace to sentient beings, not understanding what conditions to use to save and bring them peace.
Although there are these words of softness and comfort, it is not for the sake of the concentration of equanimity in loving-kindness.

Practitioners should not practice verbal loving-kindness. Some practitioners give rise to thoughts of loving-kindness, wishing to bring peace to all kinds of sentient beings. Having this mind of loving-kindness is also good, but it is not the loving-kindness of one who is fully endowed with virtue and practice.
If you wish to practice the great way, do not give rise to this kind of loving-kindness.
Here is the verse:
If practitioners of the Way give rise to thoughts of loving-kindness in their minds and mouths,
Then they themselves will have little peace and will also obtain meager blessings and virtues.
It is like a master mending arrows, dropping them into a burning fire,
How can he make those arrows
To practice the stages of the Way and establish great and vast loving-kindness, what should one do?
If a practitioner is in the heat, seeking a cool place and then feeling at ease;
in the cold, seeking warmth and then feeling at ease;
like the hungry getting food, the thirsty getting drink;
like those on a long journey, exhausted and weary, getting a vehicle and then feeling at ease;
like seeing someone standing and getting to sit comfortably;
like the weary getting to sleep peacefully;
like a naked person getting clothes and shelter;
like one with dirt on the body bathing and washing, the mind greatly delighted, peacefully and serenely settled.

Various kinds of suffering each getting what is convenient, the body and mind leaping with joy, obtaining all kinds of comfort, holding the mind unperturbed, what is lovable and respectable, relatives and loved ones, parents, brothers, wife and children, relatives, friends, and acquaintances, all causing them to be at ease;

May all sentient beings who suffer also attain peace and comfort like me. May the people of the ten directions all be liberated, with their bodies and minds at ease. I wish for both parents, relatives, and those within and outside the clan to all be at peace.
Next, think of ordinary people and so forth with kindness, extending it to enemies without any discriminatory thoughts, and cause them all to attain liberation like I have attained peace.

If in the previous thought one thinks of the people of the ten directions, and in the middle thought one thinks of enemies, and the mind is perhaps disturbed, and the initial thought cannot suddenly be equal to enemies and friends, those in the middle, one should contemplate like this:

The resentment I harbor towards enemies, this mind has already passed and is now abandoned. I will cherish them even more, thinking of them like parents, myself, children, and wife, and also like relatives, respecting them in this way, and will no longer harbor resentment.

Examining its origins, the five destinies of birth and death, sometimes as parents, family members, wives, children, brothers, or friends, but for a long time, one no longer remembers or thinks of them, therefore one should not harbor resentment.
Here is the verse:
One should cultivate a compassionate mind, thinking of enemies as good friends,
Transmigrating in birth and death, all have been close relatives.
Just as a tree produces flowers, which turn into fruits without difference,
Parents, wives, children, friends, and relatives are also like this.
The practitioner of the Way thinks to himself:
If one harbors anger towards others, it is like harming oneself!
It is like a tree producing fire that burns one's own body;
It is like a banana plant, which withers after producing fruit, or like a mule becoming endangered by carrying a foal.
I am also like this. If I harbor anger, it is the same as harming myself.ğŸ”½Here is the verse:
If one gives rise to anger towards others, one may fall into the state of a snake or enter a bad path due to this offense.
Contemplate this carefully, do not harbor evil thoughts, and if one dislikes others, one should give rise to compassion.
Here is a verse:
If one gives rise to anger and resentment towards others,
One will be reborn as a snake or a vicious animal in the future.
Just like bamboo and plantain trees, or a mule that is pregnant,
It will harm oneself in the same way, so one should give rise to a compassionate mind.

Those who cultivate the Way should practice impartial compassion, towards parents, spouse, children, siblings, friends, and even enemies, without distance or closeness, with equal compassion without aversion or attachment, and extend this to the immeasurable worlds in the ten directions, always with compassion without increase or decrease.
If one has such practice, it is in accord with compassion.
Here is a verse:
Those who practice a compassionate mind, with an impartial attitude without aversion or attachment,
Whether far or near, one should practice great compassion.
With an impartial mind, practicing great compassion, even for the people of the three realms,
One who practices compassion in this way, their virtue surpasses that of Brahma Heaven.
For those who cultivate the path and perfect a compassionate mind, they cannot be burned by fire, harmed by weapons, affected by poison, or taken advantage of by various heterodoxies.
Here is a verse:
Weapons cannot harm them, nor can officials, great enemies,ğŸ”½Evil ghosts, rÄká¹£asas, snakes, thunder and lightning,
Lions, elephants, tigers, and other harmful beasts,
None dare approach them, and none can injure them.
Cultivating the path and practicing compassion should be like this.
Sleeping peacefully at night, waking up joyfully, protected by gods and humans, never having bad dreams, with a harmonious complexion, never lacking clothing and food.
Born in the Brahma Heaven, wherever they are, they are always upright and beautiful, with clear eyes, a soft body, few illnesses, and a long life, respected by the gods;

They attain the Way and are praised by the Buddha, eliminate afflictions, and reach irreversibility, attaining peace and reaching the realm of no remainder, and attaining the liberation of tranquility, all due to the compassionate mind.
Here is a verse:
Those who practice compassion are upright and beautiful, with abundant clothing and food,
Respected by the masses, with a long life and clarity like the sun.
Sleeping, waking, walking, and stopping peacefully, the gods all protect them,
Born in the Brahma Heaven, respected by the gods, praised by the World-Honored One.
Therefore, in cultivating the Way, one should practice the compassionate mind.
Here is a verse:
Practicing the compassionate mind towards all, eliminating anger and harm, this is called compassion.
Now I have already manifested the roots of various merits, contemplating the Buddha's sutras and copying them.
Discerning and comprehending it all,ğŸ”½Beholding the Buddhas of the past,
With such clear understanding.ğŸ”½Because of right and equal enlightenment,
Therefore called a Buddha,ğŸ”½The wise and the devas and dragons,
None do not take refuge and make offerings.ğŸ”½Teaching and transforming all realms,
Removing all impurities,ğŸ”½Transforming those in evil and darkness,
Causing their minds to attain light,
Attaining peace and liberation from suffering, Removing all fears,ğŸ”½Wishing to bow to that Buddha,
Taking refuge in the most supreme.ğŸ”½The Buddha subdues the unruly,
With an elephant's roar like thunder,
Holding the resolve, the sound is heard everywhere, All are liberated forever.ğŸ”½The foolish indulge themselves,
Rushing about like a violent rain,ğŸ”½The elephant named Danbha,
With it, taming the arrogant,
And the various dragon kings, harboring poison, eyes emitting fire,
The Buddha, with his skillful transformation and rescue, his body always in tranquil meditation.
Liberated and unhindered, I now vow to bow my head,
Taking refuge in the supreme tranquility, at the feet of the World-Honored One.
Seeing Mara filled with hatred and poison, transforming everywhere into fire,
Wearing mountains and carrying weapons, holding swords and spears,
Snakes and vipers raising great trees, wanting to endanger the World-Honored One,
All the ghosts and spirits arriving everywhere, fearless and unperturbed.
Their hair like needles and knives, surrounding him on all sides,
Their number very great, not considering it frightening,
Never before frightened or doubtful, and free from all foolishness,
Having already abandoned all fears and difficulties, I vow to take refuge in the supreme one.

If one who practices the Way is in a quiet place or a secluded place, and if one is frightened, with hair standing on end, one should think of the TathÄgata's meritorious goodness, his appearance, and the Saá¹…gha of the Dharma, contemplate his precepts, discern emptiness, know the six elements and the twelve links of dependent arising, and practice kindness and compassion.
If one is frightened and thinks of these things, one will have no more fear.
Here is a verse:
Perhaps frightened, one falls to the ground, unable to correct oneself and stand in the Dharma,
Teaching one to firmly abide in the Dharma of precepts, like the wind blowing on a mountain, unable to move it.
It is like a bee collecting the flavors of flowers, I copy the sÅ«tras in the same way,
The text is very little, but the meaning is much, wanting to remove fear, therefore expounding this.ğŸ”½Originally losing the precious pearl, falling into the great ocean,
Immediately taking up a vessel, exhausting the ocean seeking the precious pearl.
Diligent and not lax, holding the mind without moving,
The sea god seeing this, immediately emerged and returned the pearl.
Just giving rise to this expedient, the king of the mind of rest,
Transcended and arrived at the great treasure mountain, not considering it lax.
Able to ultimately reach the original non-existence, bowing to the unattached,
The vow not turning back, taking refuge and paying homage to the most supreme.
Like a dragon king coiled up, sitting upright in the same way,
Seeking the Way with diligence, the great power arises and attains Buddhahood.
Walking alone for seven days, able to endure transforming women,
Bowing to that supreme one, the faith and insight not turning back.
For those practicing the Way, the mind gives rise to the thought:

Being in birth and death for incalculable eons, practicing lust, anger, and delusion for a very long time, human life is already short and moreover lazy, how can one eliminate all faults in one lifetime?
If there are such thoughts, one should contemplate like this:
It is like an old house that originally had no inhabitants. For several years, no lamps were lit. If one holds a torch and enters, the darkness will immediately disappear!
Although one has long practiced dust, dirt, and various poisons, if one has wisdom, the faults will then be extinguished.
Why is this so?
Because the power of wisdom is strong and ignorance is weak.
In this verse, it says:
If one seeks the meaning of the Way, one should not be lazy, because by obtaining the benefits of the Dharma, one can avoid decline.
By inheriting the Buddha's light of wisdom, lust, anger, and delusion are all completely extinguished.
Who can respectfully follow the Way in this way?
Only those with faith, diligence, and wisdom, who are without flattery and have determination, can respectfully practice in this way.
What is meant by faith?

Seeing and knowing that all things return to impermanence, the bodies that can be received are all worries and suffering, the three realms are all empty, and all dharmas are considered to be without self. Understanding this is called faith.
Here is a verse:
Those who practice the path, consider the world to be unstable,
All things are impermanent, and the bodies that are received are all suffering.
The three realms are all empty, and all dharmas are without self,
Where one can accept and practice, therefore it is called having faith.
If one has the thought of a self, one is a person who is upside down,
One who can understand that everything is empty, should know that this is the Buddha.
Attaining the path of sweet dew, one who awakens to this,
There is no one who can move it, this is called faith.
For one who practices the path, what is diligence?
If the practitioner is solely diligent in emptiness, the mind does not abandon it, this is called diligence.
If a forest fire burns and gradually approaches the seat, and burns the clothes, head, and eyes, one should think in the mind:
The fire burns my head, even if it burns the bones, flesh, and skin, and causes my body to die, I will never abandon the practice.
Why is it so?

Although it burns my body, it is not enough to speak of. The fire of lust, anger, and delusion in the inner body, revolving in the three evil paths of birth and death, has burned my body for countless generations, yet I have not been able to reach the ultimate in morality and virtue;

Although burning one body is not enough to save, I should only save the fire of lust, anger, and delusion with strength, and after attaining liberation, I will not retreat again. Since there is no body, there is no inner and outer suffering of fire.
This lust, anger, and delusion cannot be easily extinguished. It is like trying to melt copper and iron with chaff, which is impossible!
Holding the mind firmly and with all skillful means, one can finally eliminate the illness of lust, anger, and delusion.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Those who are solely focused on the Way and its virtue, at that time do not spare their bodies,
Like an elephant washing its body, bathing and just becoming clean, then lying down in the dirt.
If an urgent calamity befalls them, thunder and lightning do not frighten them,
Like a withered flower that people do not value, abandoning afflictions should be like this.
For one who cultivates the Way, what is called wisdom?

Understanding the time of tranquil concentration, knowing the time to contemplate, knowing the time to examine wisdom, knowing the time to receive the Dharma, clearly knowing the time of right concentration and absorption, also knowing the slow and fast times to arise from concentration;
Discerning the good and evil in one's own mind, like a good doctor knowing the illness in the abdomen!

One should control one's mind and not let it run wild, just as when a strong elephant falls into a ditch, the trainer restrains it and does not let it fall further. One who cultivates the Way and controls and cuts off external attachments should be like this.

Knowing the causes and conditions of the mind and the offerings of various thoughts, it is like a bright person knowing what food is suitable. It is also like a butcher knowing the preferences and dislikes of the ruler.
Clearly knowing the skillful means, all liberation, and the direction of progress and retreat, it is like a goldsmith distinguishing the good and bad of gold.

If one who practices the Way is apart from bright wisdom and does not understand the direction of the Way, one's mind will be fearful. Taking what is not to be what is, and what is to be not, then wisdom is not accomplished.
If one who practices the Way attains the first dhyÄna and reaches the second dhyÄna, one will be afraid and think it is losing dhyÄna, not knowing it is becoming more tranquil.
The mind thinks to itself:ğŸ”½Alas!
Confused!
The original good response, but thinking of the loss, the mind then moves away!

Being in joy and delight, away from the concentrated mind, then one's limited mind cannot proceed, harboring such doubts one then loses meditation, thinking of what is accomplished as not accomplished, and thinking of what is not accomplished as accomplished.
How does one understand the meaning of meditation?
Concentrating the mind and entering the first meditation, the mind is in the concentration of cessation, having just performed this practice and entering the second meditation.

The reason for confusion is that one has long been accustomed to worldly affairs, not yet knowing the correct truths and the end of all defilements, due to not understanding the truths, the mind is in what leaks out!
Seeking the second meditation, unable to control the mind, then one is not equipped with meditation, therefore the practitioner should know this is not it!
If the practitioner is clear and does not create this confusion, then one does not lose meditation, this is called wisdom.
Here is a verse:
If one understands the various dharmas of the body, then one knows the direction of the mind,
Skillfully restraining the mind from going astray, like an iron hook taming a white elephant.
Those who understand and penetrate the mind of concentration, discerning and contemplating in the same way,
Always with wisdom and without doubt, abiding in the Way and virtue as taught by the Dharma.
How does one who practices the Way not go astray?
It means not being deceitful, having a sincere mind, diligently practicing the Way, and being faithful and sincere.
Even if one is in practice, one does not practice. All the afflictions and impossible things are told to the Dharma teacher about their faults.
It is like a sick person with pain and suffering, who must sincerely tell the doctor about it.
The Dharma teacher observes the practitioner's intentions and, according to their deficiencies, teaches the Dharma for them.
Here is the verse:
The practitioner has a sincere mind, without deceitfulness,
Receiving the Dharma teacher's teachings, cutting off all the defilements and impurities,
Peaceful and well-purified, single-mindedly diligently cultivating the path,
Reverencing the sÅ«tras as taught by the Buddha, following the Dharma as if in battle.
If the practitioner's desires are rampant, teach them the impure nature of the human body.
There are three levels of teaching:
First, the bones of the body are like chains, supporting each other;
Second, having received the Dharma teaching, one contemplates the skull;
Third, having understood this contemplation, one further observes the forehead, focusing the mind on the head.
If anger is rampant, teach them loving-kindness. Loving-kindness has four levels:
First, parents and relatives, second, those in the middle who are neither close nor distant, third, ordinary people, and fourth, having attained this practice, equally bestowing loving-kindness.
Protecting enemies with a compassionate heart, then eliminating the nine vexations and horizontal anger.
Distinguishing this meaning, although there are close and distant, one should be detached from them.
What are the nine vexations and horizontal anger?
First, one may think to oneself:
This person has previously wronged me.
Second,
This person may later wrong me.
Third,
He is now deceiving me again.
Fourth,
In the past, he wronged my friend.
Fifth,
He may later wrong my friend again.
Sixth,
He is now deceiving my friend again.
Seventh,
That person previously respected my enemy.
Eighth,
He may later respect him again.
Ninth,
He is now respecting him again.
Although one may have these thoughts, one should discard them all.
How can one prevent others from harming oneself?
One should only guard oneself and not harm others!ğŸ”½This is the retribution for my past misdeeds and unwholesomeness, leading to this evil result!
My friend also had faults in the past, which led to this misfortune!
And if my enemy is someone who has been a close friend to me in the past, or if they have merit and are respected by others,
The three grades and nine vexations are not worth being resentful about.
What is meant by unjustified anger?
Not having seen each other before, seeing them one becomes angry.
One should then contemplate:
This person has never harmed me, and now they have no faults or mistakes. Why harbor ill-will and look down upon others?

Those who give rise to evil thoughts and unjustly inflict harm upon others will receive the punishment themselves, just as if one were to throw dust against the wind, it would only blow back onto oneself.ğŸ”½Those who practice the Way but are unable to extinguish anger and prevent it from arising, these people will not enter the stages of the Way, just as a clay pot filled with water cannot be carried far.
Those who can restrain anger, like extinguishing a fire with water, will not be harmed. This is the practice that accords with the precepts of the Way;

For this reason, even if one encounters suffering and distress, being cut by a saw, one should not give rise to anger, like a burning withered tree without a hateful mind, let alone give rise to anger towards a spiritual being!
Here is a verse:
Equally regard one's own body, ordinary people and enemies are no different,
Abandon the nine vexations, establish the will not to be angry without reason.
Control the mind and do not harbor resentment, like a withered tree without anger,
Those who practice the stages of the path are like this, without defilement.
If the practitioner has much delusion, they should contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination and discern them;
From the conditions of birth, there is aging and death. If one does not come to rebirth, then there is no beginning and end.
Here is a verse:
Without delusion, there is no birth, and the afflictions of aging and death are already removed,
Seeing the original lack of a beginning, how can one bring about the exhaustion of decline?
The causes arise from the six sense faculties, which are disturbed and thus lead to delusion,
From delusion, bonds arise, and in turn, one becomes more foolish and deluded.
If practitioners have many thoughts, they should be taught to count their breaths as they come in and out, and once the breath is stabilized, the mind becomes tranquil and free from desires.
Here is a verse:
Counting the breath, seeking stillness, and following along, seeing the true reality, the mind then stops.
Those whose nature is pure should uphold this, but sitting alone with many thoughts does not accomplish practice.
If practitioners have much arrogance, they should be taught this meaning:
People have three kinds of arrogance: first, saying I am not as good as so-and-so; second, So-and-so is equal to me; third, I am superior to so-and-so.
Those who have this thought are harboring self-importance, and should think like this:

Outside the city, in the charnel ground, discarded bones are scattered, heads and bodies in different places, without blood or flesh, the skin and flesh rot away. Go and observe this, the poor and the rich, the noble and the humble, men and women, young and old, the beautiful and the ugly, the withered bones are exactly the same, what distinctions are there?

In the end, the flesh is covered by skin, moistened by blood, and bound by sinews. Clothes, incense, flowers, and necklaces adorn the body, like an illusory transformation skillfully combined by the wind. Following the mind and consciousness, one wanders around, going to cities, countries, and villages, coming and going, moving and stopping.
Having made this observation, there is no arrogance.
One who observes the absence of inherent nature sees in the charnel ground and in all people, equality without distinction.
Here is the verse:
Those who are wealthy and noble, riding out to enjoy the city,
And those discarded in the charnel ground, considered equal without difference.
Dwelling in a quiet place, under a tree, if one contemplates in this way,
Grasping the mind and practicing the Way, the fire of arrogance cannot burn.
The Dharma master expounds the sÅ«tras and observes people's dispositions, in nineteen categories.
How does one understand this?
By discerning afflictions, one comes to know it.
What are the nineteen?

The first is greed and lust, the second is anger and hatred, the third is ignorance and delusion, the fourth is lust and anger, the fifth is lust and delusion, the sixth is delusion and hatred, the seventh is lust, anger, and ignorance, the eighth is pure speech with lustful mind, the ninth is gentle words with a hard heart, the tenth is verbal wisdom with deluded mind, the eleventh is speaking beautifully while harboring the three poisons, the twelfth is speaking roughly with a gentle heart, the thirteenth is speaking harshly with a hard heart, the fourteenth is speaking harshly with a deluded mind, the fifteenth is speaking roughly while harboring the three poisons, the sixteenth is speaking with delusion while harboring lust, the seventeenth is speaking with delusion while harboring anger, the eighteenth is speaking and mind both being deluded, the nineteenth is speaking with delusion while harboring the three poisons.
Here is the verse:
Those with lust, anger, and ignorance, combined as the three poisons,
When paired and mixed, there are four more;
Gentle speech also has four, deluded speech and deluded words have four,
The World-Honored One has spoken of nineteen kinds of human dispositions.
How does one know that a person has the characteristics of greed and lust?

One adorns oneself with joy, is of a frivolous nature, impetuous, with a hasty disposition like a monkey, and is forgetful and prone to errors. One's wisdom is deceitful and shallow, without foresight, and one's actions are reckless, disregarding what comes before and after.

One engages in unnecessary activities, is fearful, speaks much, likes to cry, is easily deceitful and submissive, and is easily comforted. One cannot endure hardship, and upon obtaining a small benefit, one greatly rejoices. One forgets small matters
but grieves greatly over them. Upon hearing others' praise, one rejoices and believes it. One reveals hidden matters
and speaks of them. One's body is warm, often soiled, with thin skin, a foul body odor, sparse body hair, much gray hair, and many wrinkles.
One does not like to grow a long beard, and white teeth appear when walking. One likes clean clothes and to wear ornaments, adorning
one's body. One likes thin clothes and often studies skills, being proficient in everything. One often goes out to play,
Always observing, joyfully smiling, adorning oneself with precepts, harmonious and respectful to elders, seeing others first and asking skillfully,
Intelligent and elegant, not stubborn by nature, ashamed and full of compassion, distinguishing good and bad, taking and giving easily,
Gentle and compassionate, bestowing favors on many, letting go and giving to relatives and friends,
Having much or little, not arguing with others, giving widely, observing the body, doing things slowly,
Understanding worldly dharmas, able to make decisions, if seeing good people, respecting and honoring them,
Quickly turning away from affairs, skilled in language, speaking gently, having many friends, but unable to be close for long,
Having little anger, respecting elders, lying down, rising, walking, not being at ease,
Although studying the Dharma, loving desires for wealth, relatives and friends, abandoning what is not firm,
Making friends not for long, hearing about sexual matters, immediately becoming attached to them, speaking of their impurity, then becoming disgusted with it, easily advancing and easily retreating.
For this reason, it is a characteristic of greed and lust.
Here is a verse:
Sudden and impetuous, light and flighty like a monkey, always happy and laughing, and also happy to cry,
Great joy in gaining profit, and great worry in losing it, much talk, and easily subdued,
Mind confused, hurried, and frightened, happy to deceive, and easily trust people's words,
Mind nature often forgetful, without foresight, fond of the precepts, and having wisdom;
Greedily gazing at form, with a good mind to give, glancing sideways at one's body, respecting friends,
Relaxed, warm-bodied, and very defiled, happy to believe, ashamed, and soft, yet courageous;
In the Dharma, wealth, form, and close friends, one cannot suddenly become estranged, and immediately regrets it,
Whatever one studies, one is able to attain it, although knowing quickly, one quickly forgets it;
Adorned with flowers and decorations on one's clothes, what one does is not important, but one respects the elderly,
The wise respect and study it with determination, penetrating and illuminating, able to understand and resolve;
Always delighting in going out of the city to travel and observe, enjoying beautiful speech and also delighting in listening,
With a sharp tongue and eloquent words, able to discriminate, unable to endure long in bed or sitting;
Gentle nature and sincerity, taking light matters to heart and not considering the consequences,
Determined and unable to endure suffering, fond of making friends and giving generously;
Disliking long beards and delighting in short ones, self-satisfied and stinking,
Crafty and many wrinkles, white, upholding precepts and wisdom unobstructed;
Seeing people first asking about their well-being, thin clothes and clean teeth,
Compassionate and easy to work with, rising to action and not sparing wealth;
Able to discern others' compassionate conduct, easy to teach and not obstinate,
The Buddha speaks of such natures, which correspond to the characteristics of lust and desire.
How should one observe the characteristics of anger?

If one is angry and difficult to understand, one has no compassionate mind. One speaks with sincerity, but with evil words and coarse speech. One harbors doubts everywhere, not seeking to believe. One delights in seeking others' shortcomings, waking up much and sleeping little. One has many enemies and friends who are difficult to reconcile. One does not forget what one has received, and is not afraid of enemies or frightening people. One has much strength and is unyielding. One has many worries and is difficult to instruct. One has a large body, a fat neck, a large head, broad shoulders, a square forehead, and good hair. One is brave, strong-willed, and difficult to subdue. What one listens to and accepts is slow and difficult to obtain. Even if one obtains it, it is also difficult to forget. If one loses wealth and wants to befriend, one will never be sorrowful. It is difficult to advance and difficult to retreat.
Knowing this, one should know the characteristics of anger.
Here is a verse:
Having a strong will and deeply understanding the meaning, one doubts everyone and seeks their shortcomings,
Having little sleep and being difficult to subdue, having a dull nature and being difficult to learn and forget;
Being able to endure hardship and being untouchable and unapproachable, having nothing to fear and not being quick to anger,
Being in accord with body and speech and being difficult to admonish and understand, being courageous and powerful while being obstinate;
Having few fears, few friends, and many enemies, having little peace and having a broad and large body,
Not regretting what should be done, abandoning the Dharma and wealth without looking back;
Once abandoning loved ones, not thinking of them, never changing or submitting,
Strenuously applying oneself and cultivating great matters, the Buddha says these are the characteristics of anger.
How does one discern the characteristics of foolishness?
It is said that one has a soft nature and delights in self-praise, lacks compassion and destroys the Dharma bridge, always
closing one's eyes and having a haggard complexion, lacking wisdom and delighting in dark places, frequently sighing
Lazy and without faith, they hate good people and always enjoy going alone. They have little knowledge and are arrogant, and their actions are
hesitant. They do not understand good or bad omens and cannot distinguish right from wrong. If there is an urgent matter, they cannot handle it themselves

and do not accept advice. They cannot distinguish between good friends and enemies and act in a contrary manner. They are as stubborn as tigers and wolves, wearing tattered clothes and with a dirty body. They are not happy by nature, and their beards and hair are
untidy and disheveled. They do not take care of themselves, worry a lot, sleep a lot, and eat too much without moderation. If someone asks them to do something,
they are unwilling to do it. If they are not asked, they do more than they should. They fear what they should not fear and do not fear what they should fear.

They worry about what they should not worry about and are happy about what they should worry about. They laugh when they should cry and cry when they should laugh. If there is an urgent matter, they are told to do it but do not do it. If they have already left, they are called back but do not look back. They always endure hardships and afflictions. When they eat or drink, they do not
They have different tastes, speak much, laugh often, forget easily, and speak heavily, biting their tongues and licking their lips while gnashing their teeth.
They walk, lie down, and rise up without ever being at ease, and in their actions and movements, there is nothing they fear or find difficult.
They do not know how to conduct themselves.
The Buddha says these are the characteristics of fools.
Here is a verse:
Weak-faced, foolish, and without compassion, with a strong forehead and self-praise,
The eyes do not blink, and one frequently sighs in frustration.
Walking alone, yet without faith, jealous of the virtuous and lazy,
Always worried and full of doubts, unable to distinguish good from evil.
The face is covered in much dust and dirt, not knowing good or bad words,ğŸ”½The actions are often chaotic, unable to complete them oneself.
What one asks to be done, one is unwilling to do, and what one does not ask to be done, one does it instead.ğŸ”½One should fear, yet does not fear, and does not fear, yet fears in return.
One should be happy, yet is sad instead, and should be sad, yet is happy in return.
When they should cry, they laugh instead, and when they should laugh, they cry instead;
They are insatiable in their greed for food and drink, and do not distinguish between enemies and those they resent,
Their disposition delights in stubbornness, and they lack wisdom and encounter suffering and distress;
Their beards and hair are always disheveled, and they lack faith and delight in dwelling in darkness,
They do not distinguish the five flavors, and they sleep a lot like tigers and wolves;
They are stingy with their views and yet arrogant, they bite their tongues and lick their lips,
They play with their mouths and delight in chewing, and what they say is often accompanied by laughter;
They are uneasy in their sleeping quarters, and it is difficult for them to advance in matters of urgency,
They call out and then rush forward, such is the nature of the characteristics of foolishness.
What are the characteristics of lust, anger, and delusion?
They are precisely the lust, anger, and delusion that were just mentioned!
The characteristics of lust and delusion, and anger and delusion, are also like this.
Those who are united with all afflictions, these are called the characteristics of lust, anger, and delusion.
Regarding this, there is a verse:
In that place, amidst dust and toil, they unite with lust and anger,
One should contemplate the characteristics of lust and anger, this is delusion and lack of wisdom.
All that was said before, the defilements of greed and desire,
Where there are actions of lust, anger, and delusion, one should know they are not apart from delusion.
What is meant by verbal desire and mental desire?
Speech is gentle, compliant, and not contrary, the body does not inflict harm on others, words and thoughts are always good, peaceful, and pleasing.
It is like a beautiful tree, its flowers are fresh and colorful, and its fruits are also delicious. Verbal desire and mental desire are also like this.
Here is a verse:
Their speech is always gentle and compliant, agreeable to others,
Words and actions are consistent, the mind and body do not harm others.
It is like a beautiful flower tree, its fruits are also sweet and delicious.
The World-Honored Buddha explains this as the characteristics of mental and verbal desire.
What is meant by verbal desire and mental anger?
Speaking softly with a poisonous heart is like planting a bitter tree, whose flowers are colorful but its fruit is extremely bitter. Speaking softly with a poisonous heart is also like this.
Here is a verse:
Their mouths speak softly, but their hearts harbor poison and harm.
They look at people with great joy, following and befriending them.
Their mouths speak gently, but their hearts contain poison.
It's like a tree with colorful flowers, but its fruit is as bitter as poison.
How do we know that the mouth desires but the heart is foolish?
Speaking softly with a dark and confused heart cannot benefit others or deceive them.
It's like a painted vase, which looks very nice on the outside but is empty and dark inside. The mouth desiring but the heart being foolish is also like this.
Here is a verse:
Their mouths speak with gentleness, but their hearts harbor dark confusion.
Know that these people have lustful mouths but foolish hearts.
Observing their mouths is like wisdom, but their minds are as dark as lacquer,
Their external appearance is like a painted vase, but their inner emptiness is also dark.
What is meant by a mouth that desires but a mind that is angry and deluded?

Their words are gentle, but their thoughts of goodness are few, their nature is unruly, they sometimes think of evil, sometimes do not think, and do not distinguish between good and evil, their nature is difficult to know.
It is like sweet medicine mixed with salt and bitterness, which cannot be distinguished. Those with a mouth that desires but a mind that is angry and deluded are also like this.
Here is a verse:
Those who speak with desire in their mouths but harbor anger and delusion in their minds,
Are like ghee and honey mixed with bitterness and salt.
What is meant by a mouth that is coarse but a mind that is lustful?
Their words are harsh and hurtful to others, they are despised by the crowd and do not want to see them, there are no respectful ones;
It is like parents scolding their children and grandchildren, although their words are harsh their hearts still love them;
It is like a surgeon who cuts and cleans a person's wound, which is very painful at the time but is greatly relieved when healed.
Those who are harsh in speech but lustful in mind are also like this.
Here is a verse:
There are those who speak harshly but harbor lust in their minds,
Like the hot sun shining on cold water in summer.
What is meant by being harsh in speech but angry in mind?
Speaking harshly, what one thinks of does not have kind compassion, not wanting others to benefit.

It is like bitter medicine mixed with poison. If one gives it to a sick person, they will spit it out and not take it. If one drinks it and it is digested, it will harm one's life. Those who are harsh in speech but angry in mind are also like this.
Here is a verse:
Those who speak harshly without respect or reverence, who think of evil and harbor poison in their minds,
Who always delight in oppressing others, one should observe that these people's actions are mixed with poison.
What is meant by being harsh in speech but foolish in mind?ğŸ”½Here is a verse:
Speaking harshly and being strict with others, one's actions are not self-aware, not thinking of others' good or evil.
It is like a thief brandishing a knife to intimidate others but unable to harm them. Such a practitioner knows to be strict in speech but foolish in mind.
Here is a verse:
Speaking harshly with a mind that does not harm, delighting in intimidating others without doing anything,
Like brandishing a knife without using it, harsh speech with a foolish mind is also like this.
What is meant by harsh speech with a mind harboring the three poisons?
Speaking harshly or being kind to others, and also adding evil, sometimes thinking unwholesome but also unable to be evil.

It is like a high official capturing a thief, and his subordinate officials fearing to question his words. Again, there are officials who encourage and ask about him, while the next subordinate official whips and beats him. Again, there are officials who do not ask about good or evil and also do not torture him. This is called harsh speech with a mind harboring the three poisons.
Here is a verse:
Their speech is harsh and urgent, their minds harbor the three poisons,
Those with such a disposition do not do good or evil;
Those with such conduct are called people in the middle,
Suffering and ease, these things are mixed together.
What is meant by a foolish mouth and a lustful mind?
They do not distinguish anything, when speaking with people they do not understand at all, they do not understand the meaning and direction of good and evil;
The mind always thinks to itself:
How can I benefit others even more!
When it comes to pursuing matters, it does not lose its original intention as it had thought.
It is like a dark night when clouds gather and rain falls, the foolish mouth and lustful mind are also like this.
In this verse it is said:
Those with a foolish mouth and lustful mind, their speech is unclear,
Like a dragon gathering clouds but not thundering, a foolish mouth and lustful mind are also like this.
What is meant by a foolish mouth and a rigid mind?
They cannot give good, nor do they add evil, always thinking in their minds:
By what means can I secretly injure others?
If they find an opportunity, they immediately harm people.
It is like covering charcoal with ash. A traveler stepping on it will be burned on the foot. The mouth is foolish and the mind is angry, also like this.
Then, in verse, it says:
The mouth is foolish while the mind is rigid, not flexible and without evil words,
Always harboring evil and adding harm to others, not thinking of the good benefits of others.
What is said is not clear, hiding evil in the mind,
Like covering charcoal with ash, if one steps on it, it will burn the person's foot.
What is meant by the mouth being foolish while the mind harbors darkness?
They cannot add good to others, nor do they add evil, and their minds do not think of the good or evil of others, without increasing or decreasing.
Why is this?
Because they have no power.

It is like a fire that has gone out covered with ashes. If one were to bring dry grass and cow dung and pile it on top, touching it with the hand and stepping on it with the foot, it would not be able to burn and bring things to maturity.
Why is this?
Because it is incapable.
The mouth being foolish and the mind being dark and confused is also like this.
Here is a verse:
The mouth has foolishness and ignorance, while the mind harbors darkness and confusion.
It cannot think of evil, nor can it think of good.
It cannot accomplish things, nor can it not do what is able.
It is like cooking in a flood, unable to bring things to maturity.
What is meant by the mouth being foolish and the mind harboring the three poisons?
The mouth does not commit offenses that do not benefit others, and it slightly injures others, thinking day and night:
By what means can I injure others?
Moreover, the mind thinks:
How can I benefit others?
Or the mind thinks:
Not harming or benefiting others.

It is like an old jar filled with clean and unclean things, with its mouth covered so that one cannot see inside. If the mouth is opened, it becomes apparent. The mouth and deluded mind harboring the three poisons is also like this.
Here is a verse:
Having a nature of delighting in contrariness, with verbal expressions not eliminating confusion,
While harboring lust, anger, and delusion, filled with foul stench.
It is like a large old jar, receiving all that is clean and unclean,
Unable to benefit people, and also completely without harm.
As a Dharma teacher, with these nineteen matters, one observes people's dispositions and preaches the Dharma for them.
What is the explanation of the characteristics of lust?
It is expounded as follows:

Those who indulge in desire fall into the hells and realms of hungry ghosts, and then emerge to become lustful birds, parrots, blue jays, pigeons, mandarin ducks, geese, ducks, peacocks, wild people, and monkeys;
If reborn as a human, they will be lustful, indulgent, frivolous, and violent.
You should observe this human body of Man, and understand that it is defiled by impurities and filth. Do not indulge in sexual desires.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Those who indulge excessively in sexual desire, with arrogance and haste,
Will be reborn as humans or animals, in the hells or as hungry ghosts.
Born there, they will harm themselves, burned by the fire of afflictions and views;
In order to liberate them from this, I teach accordingly.
If someone is very angry, he will teach the Dharma according to their conduct:

Offending and being angry with many people will lead to falling into the hells or the realm of hungry ghosts. Emerging from those evil states, one will become a poisonous animal, ghost, rÄká¹£asa, upendra-rÄká¹£asa, female ghost, or sewer ghost. One will also become a lion, tiger, wolf, snake, poisonous insect, mosquito, centipede, or millipede.
If one follows this path and returns to the world, one will have an ugly appearance and be disliked by people, always have a short life and many illnesses, and have an incomplete body.
For this reason, the consequences of misfortune are clear.
Always uphold kindness and eliminate anger.
Here is the verse:
People often harbor anger, and are disliked by the crowd.
Because of this, they fall into evil paths, have many illnesses, and are not at ease.
They fall into ghosts and poisonous beasts, and when reborn as humans, they are lowly.
Those who can practice kindness immediately eliminate the darkness of anger.
If one has much delusion, this Dharma is explained for them:

Delusion flourishes, and after death one falls into the paths of hell, hungry ghosts, or if in the animal realm, one becomes a foolish beast, such as cows, sheep, foxes, dogs, mules, donkeys, pigs, or other such creatures;

Even if reborn as a human, their nature will be indecisive, with weak eye faculties, and they will suffer from many illnesses with incomplete six sense faculties, born among barbarians and wild people, passing from darkness into darkness.
Thus, teach them to contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination, eliminating the roots of ignorance and darkness.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Those who cultivate much ignorance and darkness will have incomplete faculties,
Born among cattle and sheep, and then falling into hell;
If there are those who study and wish to transcend this evil path,
Desiring to escape its darkness, they should contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination.
If there is much lust and anger, one should practice two things:
Contemplating impurity and cultivating loving-kindness.
If there is much lust and delusion, one should expound two things:
Emptiness and loving-kindness.
If anger and delusion are rampant, one should expound two things:
Guiding with loving-kindness and understanding the roots of delusion.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Cultivating the contemplation of loving-kindness and impurity, attacking and treating lust, anger, and delusion,
Teaching the ignorant about form and the twelve links of dependent origination.
If a person has a lot of anger and ignorance, removing the darkness,
One should expound the mind of loving-kindness and the fundamental twelve links of dependent origination.
If there is oral lust with a desirous mind, one should speak of the meaning of impermanence and emptiness;
If the mind is angry and the mouth is resentful, one should expound only loving-kindness;
If the mouth is foolish and the mind is dark, one should expound the twelve links of dependent origination.
The remaining four kinds of illnesses are all present:

First, the mouth is lustful and the mind harbors the three poisons; second, the mouth is angry and lust, anger, and delusion are present; third, the mouth is foolish and the inner mind harbors the three defilements; fourth, there are people who purely harbor the three poisons.

The Dharma master who understands should expound the Dharma and teach and transform these kinds of people, causing them to be tranquil and contemplate the fundamental twelve links of dependent origination.
Why is it so?

This type of person has thick and heavy afflictions and accumulates various offenses and calamities, wrapping themselves in them. Although they do not see the truth of the sages in the present Dharma, they should only be taught to recite and encouraged to make progress. For this reason, they focus on reciting and their afflictions become thinner. Although they do not attain the Way, they can be reborn in the heavens.
Here is the verse:
Those who commit sexual misconduct, with a mind of anger and delusion,
Should be taught to recite sutras and encouraged to do meritorious deeds;
Although afflictions may flourish, because of this, they remove karmic hindrances,
And through this skillful means, they will then be reborn in the heavens.

It is like a person tending a tree garden, leveling the high and low ground, irrigating it in a timely manner, pulling out thorns, weeds, and reeds, and cutting down all the crooked and unruly growths, discarding them outside the fence to allow it to grow straight;
The trees are unobstructed, and their roots grow and flourish, all protected so as not to be broken or damaged.
For this reason, the trees grow larger and the flowers and fruits flourish.

The practitioner accepts the Dharma master's teachings, removes the defiled thoughts of desire, anger, and ignorance, and for this reason, the practice eventually grows and develops until attaining the Way.
Here is the verse:
The trees are crooked and twisted, growing sideways and not straight,
The thorns and impurities are all removed and straightened.
Using various skillful means, the trees are pruned and can then grow,
Practicing to prune the tree of Dharma is also like this.
Removing desire, anger, and ignorance, accepting the teacher's hundreds of thousands of teachings,
Eliminating all impurities, like the gardener pruning the trees.
The Dharma master expounds the sÅ«tra, observing with four things.
What are the four?
First, extensive learning leads to attaining the Way;
Second, those who welcome with the Way cannot discuss the meaning of learning;
Third, those who are knowledgeable in morality and virtue have not yet attained accomplishment;
Fourth, those who are ignorant and lack virtue.
There are also four dharmas:
First, those who initially rely on Dharma teachers to receive and understand the meaning and principles of the Dharma;
Second, although they understand the meaning, they are not subtle;
Third, they can discern shallow dharmas but not profound ones;
Fourth, they do not know the meaning and are also not clear about it.
Learning the Dharma in this way is a waste of effort.
It is like two people who are both unskilled in swimming falling into deep water, wanting to save each other but instead drowning each other;
It is like the blind leading the blind wanting to go somewhere, getting lost on the way and ultimately unable to reach their destination;
Those who do not understand the meaning also do not understand wisdom, and wanting to expound the Dharma and wanting to save others is also like this.
Here is a verse:
It is like a person who is well-versed in many good things, countless,
Having already attained the other shore, like a person who has crossed the great ocean.
If a person is pure like the truth, but lacks wisdom,
One can only grasp the essentials, but cannot attain the profound meaning.
If one practices and enters the Way, following the precepts without contradiction,
By being able to respectfully accept the teachings, there will be reciprocity in this way.
Just as by approaching the venerable ones, one will certainly attain great benefits,
Those who study and practice the Way, the meaning they seek will surely progress.
But if one only understands the progress of the meaning, and is not able to be subtle,
It is like a person eating empty soup, without any rice to go with it.
If one consults the meaning with the teacher, but does not understand the subtlety in this way,
One will not be able to understand the great Way, and will not reach the true wisdom.
Even if one does not enter the Way, one will not be able to explain it discriminatively,
Then one will not understand wisdom, and the meaning will not be clearly understood.
It is like a blind person wanting to drive another blind person, they cannot reach their destination.
Without meaning and without wisdom, it is also like this.
The practitioner considers there are three levels:
First, the body may practice the Way but the mind does not follow; second, the mind may practice the Way but the body does not comply; third, the practice of the Way is with both body and mind.
What is meant by the body practicing but the mind not following?

If the practitioner sits in the full lotus position, with the mind upright and straight like a pillar, never moving, while externally displaying this appearance, the inner mind is unrestrained, thinking of colors, sounds, smells, tastes, and textures, seeking everywhere what has been and what has not been.

The mind is unrestrained and not free, like a dead corpse abandoned in a charnel ground, fought over and eaten by tigers, wolves, birds, dogs, and foxes. The body is still while the inner mind is chaotic, it is also like this. This is for those who cultivate the Way of morality, the body is still while the mind is chaotic.
Then, a verse says:
Sitting in full lotus posture, unmoving like a great mountain,
The mind internally confused and scattered, the emotions like an elephant falling into a pit;
Thus, the practitioner's body is in concentration but the mind is disturbed,
Like a tree with crazy flowers, not bearing fruit but falling.
What is meant by the practitioner of the stages of concentration?
There is a mind in the Way but the body does not follow. The body does not sit upright to achieve the four abodes of mindfulness. At this time, the mind is concentrated but the body is uneasy.
Then, a verse says:
If the nature of the mind is self-controlled and harmonious, abiding in the four abodes of mindfulness without other characteristics,
At this time, it is called the four abodes of mindfulness. Although the body is not concentrated, the mind is not disturbed.
Practicing the stages of concentration, what is meant by the body and mind both being concentrated?
The body sits upright and the mind is not negligent. The inner faculties are all tranquil, and it also does not run outside following various conditions.
At that time, the body and mind are upright and still, and cannot be moved at all. From this we know that the body and mind are equally still.
Here is a verse:
When the body and mind are both still, the inside and outside are not negligent,
Sitting in silence with legs crossed, like a pillar, still and difficult to topple.
Seeing the truth of birth and death, like a tree floating on the shore in the water,
When the body and mind are in harmony, one quickly attains the Way and realizes the fruit.
Practicing the Way, being focused on the Way without wavering, in this way, one will quickly attain nirvana.
Here is a verse:
Expounding the essential meanings, like eating food mixed with milk and honey,
